The infirmary may start a
peer counseling program as early
as January 1981, announced
Health Services administrative
director Joan Rehner. Still in
the planning stages, the program
includes information sessions on
such topics as birth control and
responsible drinking.
The idea was first proposed at a meeting during which
the staff discussed how it could
change the infirmary's goals to
better serve the student body.
"We see one-third of the student
population," Rehner said. "The
other two-thirds are paying but
not getting anything out of it."
In addition to expanding
the infirmary's clientele, Rigner
believes the program would
also free personnel for more
skilled work. A great proportion
of the staff's time is spent
answering
simple
factual
questions about birth control,

Joseph Heller's assertion that we
are not worth our salt as a culture bears
itself out at Hopkins every day. Our
publications, supposed to provide a
showcase for Hopkins' brightest efforts,
are in a sorry state: Ellipsis, the student
literary magazine, is on the ropes financially; Ampersand, the innovative and
courageous production of last year's
freshmen, is just a memory; Zeniada
founders, unsure of itself or its contributors; (vanity and SAC budget hearings
prevent evaluation of these pages). Worst
of all, no publication offers professor's
input or widespread circulation outside
Hopkins. Which of these efforts, the N-L
included would you want to show the
world as a sterling example of Hopkins'
literary prowess?
There was, a long time ago, such a
journal. The Hopkins Review, published
between 1948 and 1953, offered a literary
forum with a national constituency. It
was a real literary review, publishing a
balanced offering of poetry and fiction
from such diverse sources as E.E.
Cummings and John Barth (described
simply as "an undergraduate"). Other
contributors, although more obscure,
offered the same high-level wOrk. In
production, also, the Review maintained a
very high standard. It rivaled the reviews
published at Kenyon and Yale. It was,
simply, good stuff.

Today, our nationally-acclaimed
English and Writing Seminars departments
offer no such thing. This is not a student
proposition— the national network a
review would need depends on the connections of our worldlier professors.
The students' need for the Review,
however, is indisputable. As a guide and
example, the simple existence of the
Review would raise the students' sagging
literacy; would promote a sense of pride
among humanities students; and would
provide an outlet for really prodigious
student work deserving wider exposure.
From the school's perspective,
there is an added incentive: it could put
Hopkins back on the literary map. The
importance of this will be attested to by
any humanities student tired of answering
-old ladies' questions about what kind of
medicine they plan to study.
The ingredients are all here. John
Irwin, chairman of the Writing Seminars
department, Was formerly editor of the
Other
prestigious Georgia Review.
professors have an impressive standing in
the literary and adacemic communities.
There is no comparable publication at
Hopkins with which it would have to
compete. The final roadblock, money, is
a red herring: the school certainly has
enough to fund the enterprise—what's
needed is a show of academic
committment.

Letters to the Editor
Dismayed At Goucher

On Providing Security

To the Editor:

To the Editor:

While recently perusing
',our publication of September
20, 1 was dismayed to find
yet another stab at the women
of Goucher College, i.e., the
Graphic located on page five.
Students at both ends of
the shuttle route may well
wonder what perpetuates the
illiberality and lack of normal
relations between Hopkins men
(and women, for that mattter),
and Goucher women. Most of
these causes seem nebulous.
There is, however, one that is
quite obvious, and I'll give you
all a clue. Check out the last
week's News-Letter, page five,
upper left hand corner. One will
find a large breasted rendition
of a giggling Goucherite, sweater
around her shoulders and all,
stalking the RAT for unsuspecting Hopkins men.
It is certainly not for lack
of sense of humor that this
attempt at humor fails to evoke
a good response - the blame rests
on the unadulterated parochialism that abounds at Homewood, and more specifically, at
your office.
If Goucher students are truly
the simpering sex kittens that
you've portrayed, why do you insist on wasting ink and paper on
them?
Mallory Knickerbocker
Class of'83
Goucher College
You have to ask?---D.N.

It is clearly the responsibility of the University to provide
adequate security services which
repond to the needs of the
Hopkins communtiy. This is
contrary to the University's
policy as reported by the Van
Driver in last week's Letters to
the Editor. The administration's
policy is dangerous, particularly
when it is used to justify the
shoddy late night escort system.
Many people must work late
on campus in labs, the computer
center, -offices and the Hutzler
Reading Room. Every one of
these people who leaves for
home after dark should be
concerned for his or her safety
when walking through the neighborhood. Unfortunately, those
who ask for an escort after the
last shuttle can leaves the
library at 1:30 am are being
harrassed. (See Corwin's "Opinion",9/26/80 News-Letter).
The officers on the late
night shift feel the security force
at night is understaffed, and
understandably they do not
want to drive off campus to
They are
provide escorts.
frustrated by these opposing
demands on their time, and thus
discourage use of the late
night escort service.
My concern is that someone
will decide to walk home alone
to avoid this abuse, and along
the way be attacked. Like the
East Baltimore campus, will the
Homewood Community wait
until there is a murder before
demanding tighter security? It is

imperative that the university
hire another. officer for the late
night shift to remedy these
problems.
All men and women working on campus late at night
should make every effort to be
done in time to take advantage
of the van service. But if you
find it is after 1:30 am and you
are tempted to walk home alone,
call for an escort instead. The
number is 338-7777. Show the
administration that the service is
needed.
Julia Skolnik
Class of 1981

Employee Corrections
To the Editor:
We, the members of the
Johns Hopkins Employees Association, very much appreciated
the article covering our group's
activities that appeared in the
News-Letter of October 3; unfortunately, the report contained a few inaccuracies. We'd like
to take this opportunity to
clarify the purpose of our
association.
The current "group" was
formed in July by a number of
individuals concerned with the
problems faced by clerical workers on campus. These individuals form the nucleus of what we
hope will be a voice for Hopkins
workers.
Our immediate goal is to
ascertain how such an organization could best serve the needs
of its members. Our experience
thus far has led us to believe that

The staff of the Student
Health Clinic will be submitting
health information articles for
the News-Letter on a biweekly
schedule entitled "Health Thyself". It is our hope to become a
more visible, out reaching service
that will be addressing important
health concerns and issues that
affect students. We welcome any
suggestions.
The topic I wish to discuss
this week is the Toxic Shock

Syndrome (TSS). This is a severe
illness characterized by sudden
onset of high fever with vomiting, diarrhea, muscle aches and
pains, followed by the development of hypotension and, in
severe cases, shock. A "sunburnlike" rash is present during the
acute phase of the illness;
about ten days after onset, there
is peeling of the skin, particularly on the palms of the hands and
the soles of the feet.
Approximately 95% of all
reported cases of TSS in women
have occurred during a menstrual period. A recent study
found a significant association
between tampon use, particularly continuous use during the
menstrual period, and the develThe risk
opment of TSS.
associated with specific brands
of tampons was further evaluated and it was found that
RELY Tampons were associated
with a statistically significant
increased risk.
Since January 1980, 299
cases of TSS have been reported;
285 (95%) of these cases have
been in women; there have been
25 deaths. Although the use of
tampons is undoubtedly an
important factor in the development of TSS in menstruating
women, the pathogenesis ot TSS
is not yet full understood.
Women can almost entirely
eliminate the risk of TSS by not
using tampons. Women who
choose to use tampons can reduce their risk by using them intermittently during each menstrual period (that is, not use
them all day and all night
throughout the period).

Muller Given Award
Steven Muller, president of
The Johns Hopkins University,
has been honored by the Federal
Republic of Germany for his
contributions to improved German-American relations.
Dr. Muller was selected by
the President of the Federal
Republic to receive the Commander's Cross of the order of
Merit - one of the highest honors
bestowed upon individuals by
that country. In a citation
accompanying the award, Dr.
Muller was praised for his
"outstanding efforts in fostering
German-American understanding
and friendship."
The decoration will be presented personally to Dr. Muller
by the Ambassador of the
Federal Republic to the United
States, Dr. Peter Hermes, at a
reception to be held October 7
at the West German Embassy in

Washington, D.C.
Dr. Muller was born in
Hamburg, Germany, and first
came to the United States in
1940. He became a naturalized
citizen in 1949.

Stanley To Launch Nationwide Search For Gifted Youth
An educational psychologist
at The Johns Hopkins University
has launched a nationwide
search for the tiny fraction of
younsters 12 and under who
show extraordinary talent in
mathematical reasoning.
Julian C. Stanley, director
of the university's Study of
Mathematically
Precocious
Youth, says the only requirement for participation in the
new program is to achieve a
score of 700 or above on the
math portion of the college
Board's Scholastic Aptitude Test
(SAT-M). The, test must be
taken before the student's 13th
birthday.
Dr. Stanley estimates there
are only 350 to 400 such young-

sters throughout the United
States.
"With proper assistance," he
says, "these superbly talented
youths will have much more
productive careers and happier
lives.
Without special help,
many will wither on the vine and
the nation will be the loser."
Those entering the new
program, which is called "700M
Before 13," will receive extensive materials designed to help
them move ahead in mathematics and related subjects at a
faster and better pace than they
otherwise would. Those who
qualify may also become eligible
tor scholarships to attend advanced summer mathematics institutes conducted by Johns

Hopkins in Maryland and by
Duke University in North Carolina.
A score of 700M on the
SAT is achieved by only five
percent of college-bound male
seniors, who are typically 17 or
18 at the time of the test. The
average college-bound male 12th
grader scored 493M, according
to recent SAT statistics.
The "700M Before 13"
program, according to Dr. Stanley, should help participating
students succeed better in later
life. As a result, he suggests,
there will be "an increase in the
number of mathematically brilliant, superbly educated mathematical and physical scientists
who will be available to make

chances of winning in November
by quoting a Lou Harris poll
that indicated up to 35 percent
of the voters had still not firmly
made up their minds. Lucey said
that if Anderson loses it will be
because of a self-fulfilling pro-

phecy, that is, that many voters
say they are not planning to vote
for Anderson because they do
not feel he can win, but if all
these people did vote for
Anderson, he would be carried
into office by a landslide.
During his speech and while
answering questions afterward.
Lucey outlined several Anderson
policy positions, including support for the Equal Rights
Amendment, and opposition to
the MX missile system.
Lucey had spent the early
morning Thursday shaking hands
with commuters in Silver Spring,
Maryland, and left the speech to
attend a lunch at the Baltimore
Anderson headquarters and then
leave for New York.

Computer Art,
Computer Music, Computer Poetry
by J.P Lewis
The computer has become a powerful tool for
the artist, not a competitor, but most artists still fail to
realize the potential of computer media. The cross-disciplinary nature of computer art is as demanding as it is
rewarding, and it is only in the domain of music that any
sort of "revolution" will occur soon. The present
experiments in computer art and computer poetry
are fascinating even in their inadequacy -- they show the
progress and problems involved in true computer art, in
which the computer is the creator as well as the executor
of the work.
COMPUTER MUSIC
For a decade synthesizers have been obligatory
equipment in the studio; they are as fundmental to
current rock and pop as the electric guitar. Recent disco
("Trans-Europe Expiess") has been entirely synthesized. While this might seem revolutionary enough, soon
we will be titillated by (another) radical change in
musical technology: digital synthesis. The difference
between analog and digital synthesizers is much more
than a matter of terminology; it involves a significantly
different, and more flexible process. An analog synthe—
sizer requires physical devices such as oscillators, frequency controls, envelope and noise generators, and
filters to produce a tone. The number of these devices
increases with the desired complexity of the sound and
the number of harmonics and simultaneous tones
required, so that a capable analog synthesizer is large,
expensive, and impossible to play. The traditional
approach to this problem has been to tape a single
harmonic or melodic line at a time and later mix all
these "voices" on a single tape. Walter/Wendy Carlos
(she had an operation) reels of the miles of tape and
months in the studio which were necessary to create
Switched-On Bach and the soundtrack of Clockwork
Orange. Although synthesizers have become more
flexible, there remains a distinction between a synthesizer intended for use in the studio, optimized toward
producing the widest possible range of sounds, and one
which can be performed "live", which has a relatively
fixed range of tone colors and frequencies, and consequently more manageable keyboards.
The digital synthesizer is actually a computer
which composes and mixes sounds mathematically
before producing them physically. While the synthesis
of complex sound by analog circuitry is limited by the
practical constraints of size and cost, a very modest
computer can, in theory, synthesize any possible sound.
Again there is a practical constraint, but one of a different order: time. Because the computer must calculate
as many as 40,000 values for each second of each
harmonic of each note of each "instrument" to be
simulated, even large computers such as the DEC-10
(used at Hopkins) may take hours to synthesize a minute
of music. Nevertheless, composer Geoffrey Wright
of the electronic music studio at Peabody considers
digital synthesis the most flexible technique of music
synthesis. He gave an example of the incredible power
of the MUS-10 music language (imported from the
Stanford music lab) which is being implemented for
music students on the Hopkins computer: the composer
can move the sound sources which are simulated by the
computer relative to the speakers and the listener. The
acoustic characteristics of various room shapes can also
be simulated, so it is possible (to use Wright's example)
to simulate a sound source which initially appears to
come from outside of the concert hall, then moves into
the room through a square (round, triangular...)pipe of
a certain size, and proceeds to execute loops in the space
above the audience's head.
These pyrotechnics are an example of the absolute control which a sophisticated digital music system
gives the composer or performer over every aspect of the
sounds in his or her music. While a traditional composer
is limited (to an extent which can only be realized with
the advent of computer-controlled synthesizers) by the

characteristics of existing instruments and especially musicians and serious composers like Wright,computers
the capabilities of the performers, a composer may have less to offer the visual artist. The critical limitation

melody demanding superhuman ability. How much of but the limited means of portraying what is created.
this capability is overkill is an important question — now Computers can be used to create fantastic designs, for
the composer will have to know the limits of human example, but these can not be fine art so long as they are

By now we are all sick of hearing forecasts of the charts of fiscal trends. Quality and texture are minor

who can't afford a DEC-10 just yet) the absolute com- important to art (including computer art) that it is even

more than a new car. Would-be composers may have
their wildest dreams realized as they rent time on a big
system or purchase a small 16- or 32- bit microcomputer with a dedicated digital music synthesizer. Much
of the technology itself is already available for the rare
music, electronics, and
individual who knows enough
computer techniques to assemble a working system.
Though each of these areas is so extensive that the
existence of such a person seems nearly hypothetical,
such people do exist: Larry Fast works on digital
synthesizers for Bell Labs ( a consistent sponsor of
advanced technology computer art and music); he also
performs a digital synthhesizer on Peter Gabriel's latest
album.
The student of computer music is faced with a
choice. A few' off-the-shelf digital systems are presently available for those who can afford them, and
more capable systems will be available soon. As was the
case with analog synthesizers, there is a distinction
between laboratory systems such as the MUS-10
language and portable --playable synthesizers such as
the Fairlight ($27,000) recently purchased by John Paul
Jones and Stevie Wonder. The alternative, for those who
cannot afford such a synthesizer or find its capabilities
lacking, is only for the very dedicated. There are a few
institutions much as the MIT music lab and the electronic and computer music studio at Peabody which
offer some instruction in computer music. In these
courses students with years of musical education and
experience must be instructed in the rudiments of
computer usage (the converse, an electrical engineering
whiz kid subjected to solfeggios, seems less likely).
To the extent that a musician is practiced, starting over
in this way will not be worthwhile. Students at Peabody
must keep up with their other studies while they are
introduced to the theory of computer music, since a
major in that field is not offered. However, the purpose of a music language such as MUS-10 is to minimize
the music students' need of computer programming
knowledge.
COMPUTER MUSIC AT PEABODY

The printer attached to the computer is one of
the earlier and most primitive computer art mediums.
The "computer nude" here was made using a printer
in conjunction with an analog-to-digital converter, a
device which converts the voltages from a light meter
behind a lens into digital measurements which the
computer uses in choosing the characters which will
compose the portrait. Ken Knowlton, a pioneer of
computer art, managed to produce fine art using this
technique. His famous "Computer Nude" is beautiful
from a distance, but when closely examined it resolves
into thousands of sub-pictures, including (he worked at
Bell Labs) Bell telephones.
The most common medium for computer art is
the plotter, a device which can draw lines of a constant
width under computer control. Early users of the
plotter noticed that plots of two- and three-dimensional
mathematical functions can pass as computer art. As a
confirmed Calcomp jockey I was lifted into higher
regions by the way 3D functions were used in the
opening sequence of Black Hole. There are an infinite
number of functions to be plotted, but none are very
profound without the accompanyment of the Disney
score. Figural drawings have also been produced with
plotters; the plot of the Hopkins campus (created for use
in an evaluation of different perspective projections)
shown here illustrates the graphic precision and artistic
monotony easily obtainable with computer graphics.
More recently it has become possible to produce
computer pictures on color video screens similar to
television sets. This medium represents a revolution
in the potential of computer art, but this potential, not
to discourage those who are spending countless hours
developing it, is far from being realized. The naive artist
and scientist may both have intuitions to the contrary,
but picture and music synthesis are two of the most
difficult areas in computing. It is rare to find a non-repetitive computer application (this excludes the U.S.
census) which requires more than a minute of computer
time (a system such as the Hopkins DEC-10 can make
tens of millions of additions in a minute), but hours are

COMPUTER ART
While digital synthesizers and computer music The abilities of the computer are most fully realized in
systems are a sophisticated medium for both popular computer animation, exemplified by Pixillation, a

film of rapidly evolving op art forms created by Ken
Knowlt6n, Stan VanDerBeek (now at UMBC), and
others at Bell Labs.
As was the case with computers themselves,
advanced computer art will employ technology originally developed for the defense and space programs. The
state of the art in both visual synthesis and animation is
indicated by an entirely computer-generated NASA film
showing the operation of the space shuttle. Computer
flight simulators, though less realistic than the NASA
promotional film, are exceptional in that the display
changes in response to the commands of the "pilot."
Imagine sitting before a video screen, selecting a particular artist's simulation, and exploring his or her world by
pushing a joystick to move in the desired direction...would this be very different from changing the channel
on a television set?
THE COMPUTER ARTIST
Computer art for the average artist is not implied
in these computer graphics systems developed in governThe introduction of
ment-sponsored laboratories.
computer-produced art into galleries alongside works in
traditional media will have to await the invention of a
"painting machine" which can compare with the subtlety and power of these media - such a device is not
presently envisioned. The development of a higher-level
art language comparable to MUS-10 will not occur in the
absence of a suitable medium, so the computer artist is
largely on his own to program the computer to create
works of art using the available devices. The artistic
potential of even the venerable plotter has not been
realized because artists are not familiar with its capabilities (or its existence?) and few are motivated to learn the
programming techniques necessary to use it on the basis
of a promise of what may be possible. With rare exceptions, "computer artists" are actually computer scientists who produce mathematical doodles in their spare
time. More capable systems may begin to attract serious
artists in the future, but the gap between technical
potential and artistic practice will continue to grow.
Technology advances at such a rapid pace that the artist
who attempts to keep up with it would have no time to
produce art. The art-science dichotomy is also reflected
in the mind. I can easily notice a "mental inertia" when
switching between tasks such as programming and
writing papers. The analytic and synthetic thought
processes required for computer art may be antithetical.

THE COMPUTER AS ARTIST
The interesting question is to what extent this
and similar experiments produce the art which they
attempt to simulate. Dr. Michael Noll (also of Bell Labs)
provides us with statistics on what is the most clearcut
case of potential computer art. He wrote a program
which randomly simulated the style of Piet Mondrian's
"Composition with Lines" (1917). A number of people
were asked which picture they preferred and which one
they thought was produced by computer. Fifty-nine
•
percent of the subjects preferred the computer composi•
tion, but only twenty-six percent correctly identified it.
A similarly successful example of the computer as artist
is the "ILLIAC suite", a musical work (composed by an
ILLIAC computer) which imitates several classical styles
with sufficient realism to fool people who are familiar
with the styles, but have not studied them.
These examples question the nature of creativity,
..
not the future of human art. What little is known about
creativity does not rule out the possibility of computer
creativity. The mathematician Poincare discerned four
stages in the creative process which have been generally .
accepted: problem definition, incubation, inspiration
and evaluation. He described incubation as the unconscious and random combination of thoughts representing
. ...... .
the elements of the problem. The many anecdotes of
creative discoveries which occur in dreams are support of
the idea that the key process in creativity is unconscious
and undetermined.
Computer-assisted creativity may not be an
unreasonable idea. An artist spends much of the time
looking for ideas, but the quality of each idea is instantly apparent when it "appears." The computer could
.......

many combinations of the problem elements defined by
the artist, whose task would be to select and develop the
best solution. The allocation of abilities is correct:
Randomness is easily accomplished by computer;
is accomplished by humans (it would be fun

to take two C.A.L. classes, one equipped with the poetry
program, the other as a control...).
In addition to the possibility of computer-aided
• creativity, creative computer programs may be useful in
that they embody a theory of the nature of their particular art, and of creativity in general. Critical theories
..
abound, but words can easily appear meaningful without
meaning much of anything. Consider this definition by
A. N. Whitehead: "Great Art is the arrangement of the
environment so as to provide for the soul vivid, but
...
transient, values." Ask the people next to you what
..
vivid but transient values are and they will probably
think you are making a Sales pitch for the Unification
Church. I remember an art instructor who used "wholeness, harmony and light" (shades of Joyce) as the
criterion of good art: very profound, but our drawing
ability did not improve. My ideas are nearly exhausted
. .
now that the "poetry" program is grammatical, but in all
.. .
the mountains of critical literature there probably is
nothing of sufficient precision to guide the first step toward making poetry. Almost nothing is known about
art in general, but it could be that there is little to know.
The role of randomness in art has been explicitly noted
many times, in Kandinski's "automatic" paintings, John
Case's musical compositions, and in the speculations of
Borges and Barth. Devoid of context and morals,
perhaps art is just the random juxtapositioning of the
elements in its media. Probably not, but this is the only
workable theory so far.

In contrast to art and music, the literary medium
is independent of its physical representation, so computer applications such as word processing do not change
literature into computer literature. In computer literature, called "poetry" because it lacks narration and
semantic content, the computer must create the work.
Although computer poetry results from a program which
exactly determines the steps used in generating a poem,
this determination is escaped by modifying the execution of the program using a random number generator.
This functions in the same way as a roll of dice: nothing truly random occurs, but the outcome is difficult
to predict and essentially random in that it is unrelated
to the task at hand.
Most computer poetry programs actually generate vocabulary lists or a "skeleton poem" at best, such as
this poem from a program by Dr. Giuseppe M. Ferrero
diRoccaferrara (sic.) at Syracuse:

The "computer poems" which sometimes find their way
into poetry collections are more properly termed
"computer-assisted" poetry (this is usually indicated in a
footnote), since they are written (by humans) using the
vocabulary lists generated by the computer as a kind
of thematic catalogue.
This poem illustrates my third attempt at a computer
poetry program:

determined by tracing random paths through a "rewrite
tree" containing rules for the expansion of various
structures of the sentence. For example, the overall
structure of the sentence results from one of the following orders of exploration of the "tree":
S S conjunction S
(Gerund Phrase)(Prepositional Phrase)
Noun Phrase Verb Phrase
(Prepositional Phrase)
where the elements in parentheses may be optionally
selected. Each of these elements is randomly rewritten
in turn, until a string of terminal markers (determine',
adjective, animate noun ...) results. The second half of
, the program selects words at random from vocabularies
structured by grammatical type and by features such as
gender and transitivity.
The most intelligent thing that the program does is to
attempt some semantic continuity by ensuring that
pronouns refer to something. This is done by keeping
track of which words have been used recently and
setting a higher probability of re-using them, and by
establishing a recurring "theme" word for the poem
(found in the title). These and similarly crude devices
create a surprisingly strong impression that the program
is actually speaking about something. Further meaning
is the result of chance; on this basis "The Reaper" is
one of best (semantically, not poetically) of several
hundred poems produced by program.

The GreatSantini
BY JOE LEVINE
Does a man, in order to be a good
father, have to be an oppressive tyrant
'against whom his children can react and
rebel? Does a boy, in order to truly
become an independent man, have to
challenge and supplant his father?
The Great Santini, a film in which
Robert Duvall portrays a bullying marine
officer who treats his wife and children
like "the troops," sends its audiences
away asking these questions. Reactions
to the film tend to be very personal, and
therefore these arguments are usually the
sort that are hard to resolve: "What a
lousy S.O.B. of a father!" (this from thin
,or:- "Those
nervous types with glasses),'
kids may hate him now, but they're
gonna thank him some day! They'll grow
up with character because of him!"
(this from people with seventeen-inch
collars).
Regardless of whether one approves of Bull Meechum (the character
played by Duvall) as a father, The Great
Santini is likely to please as intelligent
and lively entertainment. The relationship between Bull and his sensitive,
gentle son Ben (Michael O'Keefe) rings
Even without Bull's external
true.
marine trappings, with all the violent,
ritualistic, and even childish behavior
these entail, and even without the dramatic responsibilities thrust upon the
eighteen-year-old Ben by the sometimes
contrived plot of the film, The Great
Santini succeeds as the story of two
believable and diametrically opposed
personalities who have had the odd
fortune to be thrown together in life
as father and son.
The film, when dealing with this,
its essential subject, surpasses other
popular-audience films of recent years
which have attempted to deal with the

complex psychology of family relationFilms such as An Unmarried
ships.
Woman and Kramer Vs. Kramer are
somewhat marred by glib plot development, reminiscent of situation comedy,
while The Great Santini is, at its best,
brutally realistic when dealing with
father, mother and son. The violence
Bull does to his wife and son prevents
him from being merely a loveable bully
and bigot, like TV's Archie Bunker. Ben's
conflicting feelings of love and truly
destructive hatred for his father are what
we want and expect to see after our
exposure to Bull, and establish the son as
a major character in the film, unlike the
one-dimensional children in An Unmarried Woman or Neil Simon's Goodbye
Girl. And Bull's wife, played by Blythe
Danner, is a fascinating mixture of
submissiveness to her tyrant husband and
silent strength in her struggle to raise her
children as both sensitive spirits and the
offspring of the great Bull Meechum.
Each of the three main characters
is satisfyingly complex, and convincingly
acted; it is questionable who - Duvall,
O'Keefe, or Danner - walks off with
the movie, although my vote, personally,
is for O'Keefe, whose role is perhaps the
most difficult.

Rauschenberg Works On Display
BY MARK SKONER
Noting Robert Rauschenberg's
long-term involvement with most of the
ideas, attitudes, and techniques essential
to pop art, a critic in 1965 call him "the
Old Master of the new painting." Today
that apellation is even more fitting, as
Rauschenberg's sixtieth birthday approaches, and one realizes that for thirty
years he has been a symbol of the new.
During the past decade, while his
earlier work has continued to attract
considerable attention, he has been a
prolific source of fresh concepts. No
longer an enfant terrible, but still an
innovator, Rauschenberg remains basically concerned with creating artistic experiences which can delight and astonish,
rather than with using any particular

stylistic or theoretical approach. The
Baltimore Museum has organized a
retrospective exhibition focused on over a
dozen of Rauschenberg's major works
dating from 1971 to 1980.
Rauschenberg's combines and
collages from the 1950's and 1960's have
become classics of American art. The
issues raised by his freewheeling approach
to art are now elements of aesthetic

ahead of the critics and theoreticians,

artists did during the 60's. He has also
been able to achieve popularity among

The Veal" Woody Allen
BY STEPHEN H. BARR
Towards the middle of Stardust
Memories, Woody Allen's new film, a
struggling actor intercepts the worldfamous film director Sandy Bates(Woody
Allen) in a hotel lobby and says "I love
you. I mean, I love your work." This
slip is the essence of the film.
Throughout Woody Allen's career
as a comedian and a director, we have
assumed (as this actor does) that we can
understand Allen the man through his
work. In Allen's case, because he _stars in
' his own films, , he acknowledges the
autobiographical nature of his work, and
is often the butt of his funniest jokes, it is
particularly difficult to distinguish between the man and the work. Stardust
Memories is the ultimate autobiography,
in which Allen portrays a character we

immediately want to assume is himself - a
famous director of comedies.
This
character, Sandy Bates, proves to be the
most confusing and dislikable of Allen's
screen personas.
Bates is a director who makes
people laugh, but he is obsessed with
human suffering, which he considers
more important. His problem is not a
lack of inspiration, but of room to
create freely. At a weekend retrospective
of Bates' films, Allen surrounds Bates
with fawning fans who prey on his
privacy, his creativity, and his ability to
be Sandy Bates. Allen fills every corner
of his film with a supporting cast of sad
and grotesque creatures who become the
visual embodiment of what is stifling
Bates.

OCTOBER 10, 1980 / PAGE 14

Nosey Kitty Kats

Chinatown: Film-Noir In Color
BY DAISY TAYLOR
Roman Polanski's Chinatown, starring Jack Nicholson, Faye Dunaway, and
John Huston, is film-noir in color. It is
hard-boiled cinema with an extra turn of
the screw. Polanski has protrayed a
thirsty Los Angeles summer in 1938 that
is seamier and more highly charged
with violence than it was in The Maltese
Falcon, The Big Sleep or Double Indemnity, but maintains the suspenseful, yet
brooding quality that those films had. He
lavishes the same attention onobjects and
details; we know what time it is, what
people drink and eat, their names, addresses and how they light their cigarettes. Polanski and his characters often
brilliantly mock the conventions of the
genre. But as a whole the film's message
is more shattering and its outlook more
bleak than its predecessors.
Jack Nicholson plays J.J. Giddes, a
small-time private eye, the smooth-talking
tough guy (especially likeable for being
something of a bumbler), whc, wants to
work outside the system and will spare
the little man if he can to get at the real
power figures behind him. Nicholson is
at his best in this role, bringing sensitivity
to a slick portrayal. Giddes is smart and
quick, but while working on a routine
adultery case, he stumbles into a complex

political moneymaking plot involving the
Los Angeles water supply (based on the
Otises and Chandlers scandal in 1905)
that is over his head. We move with
Giddes through LA's dried up river beds
and terra cotta court apartments under an
electric blue sky and a merciless sun. He
makes his way through a throng of
suspicious characters; twitching politicians, a hand-wringing rest home director, a
stone-faced Chinese butler, and a midget
mafioso with a stilletto. Everyone has
shifty eyes including Faye Dunaway, who
plays Mrs. Evelyn Molwray. Her husband
Hollis Molwray's role in the plot as
Commissioner of Water and Power for
Los Angeles puts her in the center of the
intrigue, making her a figure who seems
to attract violence from everyone including Giddes. Giddes is given a chance to
get out of it all, but true to the genre,
he falls in love with Mrs. Molwray, tries
to help her, and she, as we might expect,
never plays straight with him until it is
too late.
John Huston, as Dunaway's father,
the mysterious ranch magnate Noah
Cross, is also a party in the water plot.
Since John Huston also directed The
Maltese Falcon, one might suspect
that he worked in cahoots with Polanski
on this film. It seems appropriate that,
though they never appear together in the
film, they seem to play perverted versions
of the Falcon's sinister twosome, Sidney
Greenstreet and Peter Lorre. Huston is a
reptilian bulk wearing white, a characature of the slow moving villain who
knows how to live well.
However,
Cross is dangerous and unstoppable in a
way that Sidney Greenstreet never was.
Speaking in a coarse varody of Lorre's
seductive whine, Polanski plays the
rat-like midget who slits Nicholson's nose
with his stilletto. He is no pseudo-sophisticated dandy but coldly acts out his
playful threat as an enjoyable routine. As
he warns Nicholson,"Do you know what
happens to nosey kitty cats?", on the
screen he is directly facing the viewer.
Perhaps he is addressing his nosey audi-

ence too, warning us that we might
be in for a nasty surprise. We are shocked and disgusted by the violence of his
ensuing act. Through this self-reflexivity,
he is telling us that this is a more dangerous film than it's predecessor; anything
can happen. There's no pussy-footing
here.
Very little of the film's action takes
place
Chinatown.

Rauschenberg Show
cont.from p. 13
The complete work is a field containing
many incidents. One's attention moves
from detail to detail - the painting must
be read, not perceived in a single glance.
Cloth has become the dominant iredium.
Rauschenberg used cloth in the early
50's, but not extensively. Now,he seems
to be reveling in the tremendous range
of patterns, colors, and textures available
to him. This switch from paint to fabric
is undoubtedly responsible for Rauschenberg's abandonment of silk-screened
images. Now he has returned. to a technique he developed in the 50's: solvent
transfer, a simple way of moving a
magazine photo from its paper substrate
directly onto cloth, with little change
in color or definition. In effect, the
image soaks right into the cloth, whereas
a silk-screened image is printed onto a
canvas with paint.
In every collage, cloth patches
recall curtains, clothing, tablecloths,
sheets, and upholstery: this sets up a
nostalgic or homey atmosphere, especially when the images cooperate (as they
often do). The direct presentation of the
photographic images is analogous to
homemade shrines (a wall in grandma's
house) or lockerroom pinups - the bulletin-board principle of tacking up transient
images.
Rauschenberg has gotten away
from highly urban, technological images,
again harking back to the 50's. Images of

Faye Dunaway as Mrs. Evelyn Molwray
The music, along with the camera
work, keeps up the suspense throughout.
Using camera techniques similar to those
employed in The Maltese Falcon,
Polanski often traps the character in a
tight frame. Cutting in very close to
Nicholson, he shows the viewer little of
the area surrounding him so that violence
always seems to tremble at the edge
of the screen.
In many ways Chinatown is more
than a suspense thriller. As Polanski
heightens the violence, Nicholson adds a
layer of sensitivity and vulnerability to
Giddes' character. With a tragic inevitability the two clash in a conclusion that
will probably leave you speechless no
matter how many times you've seen the
film before.

Clippers Open Oct. 25th

Charm City's Own Hockey Sensations Return
BY DAVE E1NOLF
During a press conference
held last week , the Baltimore
Clippers hockey team announced their 1980-81 season
schedule and ticket prices. The
Clippers als the signing of a
contract with WCBM radio, 680
AM, to broadcast the play-by-play for all 36 of the Clippers
regular season road games.
The Clippers will open their
home season Saturday, October
25th with an 8 o'clock contest
against the Richmond Rifles.
The Rifles, a farm team for the
New York Rangers, were one of
the Clippers' toughest opponents
in last year's maiden season.
Ticket for Clippers games are
$6.00 and $5.00, with special
$2.50 Upper Concourse seats
available immediately
at
all Hecht Co. Stores and the
Civic Center.
The Clippers schedule features 35 home games this season,
each as exciting as the opener
promises to be. Although the
Clippers have lost five of their
top players to the Minnesota
North Stars and their Oklahome
City farm team, skaters Barry
Alter, Gerry Ciarcia, Wes Coulson, Dave Herbst, Pierre Lagace,
Paul Pacific, and Tony Thomas
will al return when the Clippers
open their training camp at the
Civic Center October 14th. The
Clippers leading front line from
last season, that of Warren
Young, Ron Friest, and Henry
Taylor, has moved up, and Ron
Friest has been retained on the
North Stars roster even at this

late date. Goalie Jim Weaver,
who led the EHL in saves and
least goals scored, has hoped on
starting for _Oklahoma City this
season.
In addition to the seventeen
players on the roster announced
to date, the Clippers will be
holding a free agent trainin

camp 'this week, and will bring
around forty players to the Civic
Center in hopes of forming a
solid eighteen-man roster before
the start of the season.
Hockey fans should look for
intense competition among the
Clippers, the Richmond Rifles,
and Erie Blades. While these
three teams were all outstanding
in alst year's end-of-season
Mitchell Cup competition, fans
should by no means expect the

•

N-L
SPORTS

others to be lacking. The newly
formed Salem (Va.) Raiders and
the Syracuse Hornets, as well
as the returning Hampton (Va.)
Aces, should all add spice to the
season schedule. At the price
these tickets go for, the Clippers
cost less than a movie, and the
action is twice as intense. There
are no bad seats in the Civic
Center, because of the small
size of the arena. While seating
10,000 fans, the Civic Center

allows each of them an excellent
view. College students will be
wooed with various promotions
throughout the season, so watch
for them.
Finally, the front office is
conducting a talent search of
sorts, looking for performers to
fill in between periods and to
sing the Star-Spangled Banner.
All those interested should
phone Gary Thomas of the
Clippers at 727-0703.

Quiz Results
This week's quiz competition wasn't overwhelmingly heavy,
but we had our fair share of fine answers. Dorothy Pierson, David
Hollander and Eric Rocheteau all receive kudos for the most
correct answers. Although Pierson's and Rocheteau's subjective
answers were the best the quiz maestros still subjected it to the
luck of the draw. The winner was Eric Rocheteau of 4 E. 32nd
St.
The correct answers to this unbelievably tough quiz were:
I. Luis Aparicio; 2. Felix; 3. Allie Reynolds; 4. Jack Billingham:
5. Cesar Tovar; 6. Tim Foli; 7. Dave Leonhard; 8. Vida Blue; 9.
Johnny Oates; 10. Luis Tiant; 11. Tony . Chavez; 12. Alfred
Manuel Martin (from Number 1.); 13. Mike Cuellar; 14. Sam
McDowell; 15. Pat Kelly; 16. Clint Courtney; 17. Pat Dobson; 18.
36, Hal Brown; 19. Bob Feller pitched an Opening Day no-hitter.
Subjectively, the Mets have spawned more great players than
any other team in the last years. The whole idea, Dorothy, is that
they did trade them away, that's why the Mets are so much fun.
The Orioles, Dave, was not the right answer. As for broadcasters:
Howard Cosell was the right pick, but Tom Marr was almost as
good.

The infirmary may start a
peer counseling program as early
as January 1981, announced
Health Services administrative
director Joan Rehner. Still in
the planning stages, the program
includes information sessions on
such topics as birth control and
responsible drinking.
The idea was first proposed at a meeting during which
the staff discussed how it could
change the infirmary's goals to
better serve the student body.
"We see one-third of the student
population," Rehner said. "The
other two-thirds are paying but
not getting anything out of it."
In addition to expanding
the infirmary's clientele, Rigner
believes the program would
also free personnel for more
skilled work. A great proportion

Joseph Heller's assertion that we
are not worth our salt as a culture bears
itself out at Hopkins every day. Our
publications, supposed to provide a
showcase for Hopkins' brightest efforts,
are in a sorry state: Ellipsis, the student
literary magazine, is on the ropes financially; Ampersand, the innovative and
courageous production of last year's
freshmen, is just a memory; Zeniada
founders, unsure of itself or its contributors; (vanity and SAC budget hearings
prevent evaluation of these pages). Worst
of all, no publication offers professor's
input or widespread circulation outside
Hopkins. Which of these efforts, the N-L
included would you want to show the
world as a sterling example of Hopkins'
literary prowess?
There was, a long time ago, such a
journal. The Hopkins Review, published
between 1948 and 1953, offered a literary
forum with a national constituency. It
was a real literary review, publishing a
balanced offering of poetry and fiction
from such diverse sources as E.E.
Cummings and John Barth (described
simply as "an undergraduate"). Other
contributors, although more obscure,
offered the same high-level wOrk. In
production, also, the Review maintained a
very high standard. It rivaled the reviews
published at Kenyon and Yale. It was,
simply, good stuff.

Today, our nationally-acclaimed
English and Writing Seminars departments
offer no such thing. This is not a student
proposition— the national network a
review would need depends on the connections of our worldlier professors.
The students' need for the Review,
however, is indisputable. As a guide and
example, the simple existence of the
Review would raise the students' sagging
literacy; would promote a sense of pride
among humanities students; and would
provide an outlet for really prodigious
student work deserving wider exposure.
From the school's perspective,
there is an added incentive: it could put
Hopkins back on the literary map. The
importance of this will be attested to by
any humanities student tired of answering
-old ladies' questions about what kind of
medicine they plan to study.
The ingredients are all here. John
Irwin, chairman of the Writing Seminars
department, Was formerly editor of the
Other
prestigious Georgia Review.
professors have an impressive standing in
the literary and adacemic communities.
There is no comparable publication at
Hopkins with which it would have to
compete. The final roadblock, money, is
a red herring: the school certainly has
enough to fund the enterprise—what's
needed is a show of academic
committment.

To the Editor:

While recently perusing

The staff of the Student
Health Clinic will be submitting
health information articles for
the News-Letter on a biweekly
schedule entitled "Health Thyself". It is our hope to become a
more visible, out reaching service
that will be addressing important
health concerns and issues that
affect students. We welcome any
suggestions.
The topic I wish to discuss
this week is the Toxic Shock

Syndrome (TSS). This is a severe
illness characterized by sudden
onset of high fever with vomiting, diarrhea, muscle aches and
pains, followed by the development of hypotension and, in
severe cases, shock. A "sunburnlike" rash is present during the
acute phase of the illness;
about ten days after onset, there
is peeling of the skin, particularly on the palms of the hands and
the soles of the feet.
Approximately 95% of all
reported cases of TSS in women
have occurred during a menstrual period. A recent study
found a significant association
between tampon use, particularly continuous use during the
menstrual period, and the develThe risk
opment of TSS.
associated with specific brands
of tampons was further evaluated and it was found that
RELY Tampons were associated
with a statistically significant
increased risk.
Since January 1980, 299
cases of TSS have been reported;
285 (95%) of these cases have
been in women; there have been
25 deaths. Although the use of
tampons is undoubtedly an
important factor in the development of TSS in menstruating
women, the pathogenesis ot TSS
is not yet full understood.
Women can almost entirely
eliminate the risk of TSS by not
using tampons. Women who
choose to use tampons can reduce their risk by using them intermittently during each menstrual period (that is, not use
them all day and all night
throughout the period).

Muller Given Award
Steven Muller, president of

has been honored by the Federal

contributions to improved German-American relations.

the President of the Federal
Republic to receive the Commander's Cross of the order of
Merit - one of the highest honors
bestowed upon individuals by
that country. In a citation
accompanying the award, Dr.
Muller was praised for his
"outstanding efforts in fostering
German-American understanding
and friendship."

by the Ambassador of the
Federal Republic to the United
States, Dr. Peter Hermes, at a
reception to be held October 7
at the West German Embassy in

Washington, D.C.

Hamburg, Germany, and first
came to the United States in
1940. He became a naturalized
citizen in 1949.

An educational psychologist

math portion of the college

(SAT-M). The, test must be

birthday.

sters throughout the United
States.
"With proper assistance," he

youths will have much more
productive careers and happier
lives.
Without special help,
many will wither on the vine and
the nation will be the loser."

otherwise would. Those who
qualify may also become eligible
tor scholarships to attend advanced summer mathematics institutes conducted by Johns

Hopkins in Maryland and by
Duke University in North Carolina.

SAT is achieved by only five
percent of college-bound male

18 at the time of the test. The
average college-bound male 12th
grader scored 493M, according
to recent SAT statistics.
The "700M Before 13"
program, according to Dr. Stanley, should help participating
students succeed better in later
life. As a result, he suggests,
there will be "an increase in the
number of mathematically brilliant, superbly educated mathematical and physical scientists

Computer Art,
Computer Music, Computer Poetry
by J.P Lewis
The computer has become a powerful tool for
the artist, not a competitor, but most artists still fail to
realize the potential of computer media. The cross-disciplinary nature of computer art is as demanding as it is
rewarding, and it is only in the domain of music that any
sort of "revolution" will occur soon. The present
experiments in computer art and computer poetry
are fascinating even in their inadequacy -- they show the
progress and problems involved in true computer art, in
which the computer is the creator as well as the executor
of the work.
COMPUTER MUSIC
For a decade synthesizers have been obligatory
equipment in the studio; they are as fundmental to
current rock and pop as the electric guitar. Recent disco
("Trans-Europe Expiess") has been entirely synthesized. While this might seem revolutionary enough, soon
we will be titillated by (another) radical change in
musical technology: digital synthesis. The difference
between analog and digital synthesizers is much more
than a matter of terminology; it involves a significantly
different, and more flexible process. An analog synthe—
sizer requires physical devices such as oscillators, frequency controls, envelope and noise generators, and
filters to produce a tone. The number of these devices
increases with the desired complexity of the sound and
the number of harmonics and simultaneous tones
required, so that a capable analog synthesizer is large,
expensive, and impossible to play. The traditional
approach to this problem has been to tape a single
harmonic or melodic line at a time and later mix all
these "voices" on a single tape. Walter/Wendy Carlos
(she had an operation) reels of the miles of tape and
months in the studio which were necessary to create
Switched-On Bach and the soundtrack of Clockwork
Orange. Although synthesizers have become more
flexible, there remains a distinction between a synthesizer intended for use in the studio, optimized toward
producing the widest possible range of sounds, and one
which can be performed "live", which has a relatively
fixed range of tone colors and frequencies, and consequently more manageable keyboards.
The digital synthesizer is actually a computer
which composes and mixes sounds mathematically
before producing them physically. While the synthesis
of complex sound by analog circuitry is limited by the
practical constraints of size and cost, a very modest
computer can, in theory, synthesize any possible sound.
Again there is a practical constraint, but one of a different order: time. Because the computer must calculate
as many as 40,000 values for each second of each
harmonic of each note of each "instrument" to be
simulated, even large computers such as the DEC-10
(used at Hopkins) may take hours to synthesize a minute
of music. Nevertheless, composer Geoffrey Wright
of the electronic music studio at Peabody considers
digital synthesis the most flexible technique of music
synthesis. He gave an example of the incredible power
of the MUS-10 music language (imported from the
Stanford music lab) which is being implemented for
music students on the Hopkins computer: the composer
can move the sound sources which are simulated by the
computer relative to the speakers and the listener. The
acoustic characteristics of various room shapes can also
be simulated, so it is possible (to use Wright's example)
to simulate a sound source which initially appears to
come from outside of the concert hall, then moves into
the room through a square (round, triangular...)pipe of
a certain size, and proceeds to execute loops in the space
above the audience's head.
These pyrotechnics are an example of the absolute control which a sophisticated digital music system
gives the composer or performer over every aspect of the
sounds in his or her music. While a traditional composer
is limited (to an extent which can only be realized with
the advent of computer-controlled synthesizers) by the

characteristics of existing instruments and especially musicians and serious composers like Wright,computers

their wildest dreams realized as they rent time on a big
system or purchase a small 16- or 32- bit microcomputer with a dedicated digital music synthesizer. Much
of the technology itself is already available for the rare
music, electronics, and
individual who knows enough
computer techniques to assemble a working system.
Though each of these areas is so extensive that the
existence of such a person seems nearly hypothetical,
such people do exist: Larry Fast works on digital
synthesizers for Bell Labs ( a consistent sponsor of
advanced technology computer art and music); he also
performs a digital synthhesizer on Peter Gabriel's latest
album.
The student of computer music is faced with a
choice. A few' off-the-shelf digital systems are presently available for those who can afford them, and
more capable systems will be available soon. As was the
case with analog synthesizers, there is a distinction
between laboratory systems such as the MUS-10
language and portable --playable synthesizers such as
the Fairlight ($27,000) recently purchased by John Paul
Jones and Stevie Wonder. The alternative, for those who
cannot afford such a synthesizer or find its capabilities
lacking, is only for the very dedicated. There are a few
institutions much as the MIT music lab and the electronic and computer music studio at Peabody which
offer some instruction in computer music. In these
courses students with years of musical education and
experience must be instructed in the rudiments of
computer usage (the converse, an electrical engineering
whiz kid subjected to solfeggios, seems less likely).
To the extent that a musician is practiced, starting over
in this way will not be worthwhile. Students at Peabody
must keep up with their other studies while they are
introduced to the theory of computer music, since a
major in that field is not offered. However, the purpose of a music language such as MUS-10 is to minimize
the music students' need of computer programming
knowledge.
COMPUTER MUSIC AT PEABODY

The printer attached to the computer is one of
the earlier and most primitive computer art mediums.
The "computer nude" here was made using a printer
in conjunction with an analog-to-digital converter, a
device which converts the voltages from a light meter
behind a lens into digital measurements which the
computer uses in choosing the characters which will
compose the portrait. Ken Knowlton, a pioneer of
computer art, managed to produce fine art using this
technique. His famous "Computer Nude" is beautiful
from a distance, but when closely examined it resolves
into thousands of sub-pictures, including (he worked at
Bell Labs) Bell telephones.
The most common medium for computer art is
the plotter, a device which can draw lines of a constant
width under computer control. Early users of the
plotter noticed that plots of two- and three-dimensional
mathematical functions can pass as computer art. As a
confirmed Calcomp jockey I was lifted into higher
regions by the way 3D functions were used in the
opening sequence of Black Hole. There are an infinite
number of functions to be plotted, but none are very
profound without the accompanyment of the Disney
score. Figural drawings have also been produced with
plotters; the plot of the Hopkins campus (created for use
in an evaluation of different perspective projections)
shown here illustrates the graphic precision and artistic
monotony easily obtainable with computer graphics.
More recently it has become possible to produce
computer pictures on color video screens similar to
television sets. This medium represents a revolution
in the potential of computer art, but this potential, not
to discourage those who are spending countless hours
developing it, is far from being realized. The naive artist
and scientist may both have intuitions to the contrary,
but picture and music synthesis are two of the most
difficult areas in computing. It is rare to find a non-repetitive computer application (this excludes the U.S.
census) which requires more than a minute of computer
time (a system such as the Hopkins DEC-10 can make
tens of millions of additions in a minute), but hours are

COMPUTER ART
While digital synthesizers and computer music The abilities of the computer are most fully realized in
systems are a sophisticated medium for both popular computer animation, exemplified by Pixillation, a

film of rapidly evolving op art forms created by Ken
Knowlt6n, Stan VanDerBeek (now at UMBC), and
others at Bell Labs.
As was the case with computers themselves,
advanced computer art will employ technology originally developed for the defense and space programs. The
state of the art in both visual synthesis and animation is
indicated by an entirely computer-generated NASA film
showing the operation of the space shuttle. Computer
flight simulators, though less realistic than the NASA
promotional film, are exceptional in that the display
changes in response to the commands of the "pilot."
Imagine sitting before a video screen, selecting a particular artist's simulation, and exploring his or her world by
pushing a joystick to move in the desired direction...would this be very different from changing the channel
on a television set?
THE COMPUTER ARTIST
Computer art for the average artist is not implied
in these computer graphics systems developed in governThe introduction of
ment-sponsored laboratories.
computer-produced art into galleries alongside works in
traditional media will have to await the invention of a
"painting machine" which can compare with the subtlety and power of these media - such a device is not
presently envisioned. The development of a higher-level
art language comparable to MUS-10 will not occur in the
absence of a suitable medium, so the computer artist is
largely on his own to program the computer to create
works of art using the available devices. The artistic
potential of even the venerable plotter has not been
realized because artists are not familiar with its capabilities (or its existence?) and few are motivated to learn the
programming techniques necessary to use it on the basis
of a promise of what may be possible. With rare exceptions, "computer artists" are actually computer scientists who produce mathematical doodles in their spare
time. More capable systems may begin to attract serious
artists in the future, but the gap between technical
potential and artistic practice will continue to grow.
Technology advances at such a rapid pace that the artist
who attempts to keep up with it would have no time to
produce art. The art-science dichotomy is also reflected
in the mind. I can easily notice a "mental inertia" when
switching between tasks such as programming and
writing papers. The analytic and synthetic thought
processes required for computer art may be antithetical.

THE COMPUTER AS ARTIST
The interesting question is to what extent this
and similar experiments produce the art which they
attempt to simulate. Dr. Michael Noll (also of Bell Labs)
provides us with statistics on what is the most clearcut
case of potential computer art. He wrote a program
which randomly simulated the style of Piet Mondrian's
"Composition with Lines" (1917). A number of people
were asked which picture they preferred and which one
they thought was produced by computer. Fifty-nine
•
percent of the subjects preferred the computer composi•
tion, but only twenty-six percent correctly identified it.
A similarly successful example of the computer as artist
is the "ILLIAC suite", a musical work (composed by an
ILLIAC computer) which imitates several classical styles
with sufficient realism to fool people who are familiar
with the styles, but have not studied them.
These examples question the nature of creativity,
..
not the future of human art. What little is known about
creativity does not rule out the possibility of computer
creativity. The mathematician Poincare discerned four
stages in the creative process which have been generally .
accepted: problem definition, incubation, inspiration
and evaluation. He described incubation as the unconscious and random combination of thoughts representing
. ...... .
the elements of the problem. The many anecdotes of
creative discoveries which occur in dreams are support of
the idea that the key process in creativity is unconscious
and undetermined.
Computer-assisted creativity may not be an
unreasonable idea. An artist spends much of the time
looking for ideas, but the quality of each idea is instantly apparent when it "appears." The computer could

In addition to the possibility of computer-aided
• creativity, creative computer programs may be useful in
that they embody a theory of the nature of their particular art, and of creativity in general. Critical theories
..
abound, but words can easily appear meaningful without
meaning much of anything. Consider this definition by
A. N. Whitehead: "Great Art is the arrangement of the
environment so as to provide for the soul vivid, but
...
transient, values." Ask the people next to you what
..
vivid but transient values are and they will probably
think you are making a Sales pitch for the Unification
Church. I remember an art instructor who used "wholeness, harmony and light" (shades of Joyce) as the
criterion of good art: very profound, but our drawing
ability did not improve. My ideas are nearly exhausted
. .
now that the "poetry" program is grammatical, but in all
.. .
the mountains of critical literature there probably is
nothing of sufficient precision to guide the first step toward making poetry. Almost nothing is known about
art in general, but it could be that there is little to know.
The role of randomness in art has been explicitly noted
many times, in Kandinski's "automatic" paintings, John
Case's musical compositions, and in the speculations of
Borges and Barth. Devoid of context and morals,
perhaps art is just the random juxtapositioning of the
elements in its media. Probably not, but this is the only
workable theory so far.

In contrast to art and music, the literary medium
is independent of its physical representation, so computer applications such as word processing do not change
literature into computer literature. In computer literature, called "poetry" because it lacks narration and
semantic content, the computer must create the work.
Although computer poetry results from a program which
exactly determines the steps used in generating a poem,
this determination is escaped by modifying the execution of the program using a random number generator.
This functions in the same way as a roll of dice: nothing truly random occurs, but the outcome is difficult
to predict and essentially random in that it is unrelated
to the task at hand.
Most computer poetry programs actually generate vocabulary lists or a "skeleton poem" at best, such as
this poem from a program by Dr. Giuseppe M. Ferrero
diRoccaferrara (sic.) at Syracuse:

The "computer poems" which sometimes find their way
into poetry collections are more properly termed
"computer-assisted" poetry (this is usually indicated in a
footnote), since they are written (by humans) using the
vocabulary lists generated by the computer as a kind
of thematic catalogue.
This poem illustrates my third attempt at a computer
poetry program:

determined by tracing random paths through a "rewrite
tree" containing rules for the expansion of various
structures of the sentence. For example, the overall
structure of the sentence results from one of the following orders of exploration of the "tree":
S S conjunction S
(Gerund Phrase)(Prepositional Phrase)
Noun Phrase Verb Phrase
(Prepositional Phrase)
where the elements in parentheses may be optionally
selected. Each of these elements is randomly rewritten
in turn, until a string of terminal markers (determine',
adjective, animate noun ...) results. The second half of
, the program selects words at random from vocabularies
structured by grammatical type and by features such as
gender and transitivity.
The most intelligent thing that the program does is to
attempt some semantic continuity by ensuring that
pronouns refer to something. This is done by keeping
track of which words have been used recently and
setting a higher probability of re-using them, and by
establishing a recurring "theme" word for the poem
(found in the title). These and similarly crude devices
create a surprisingly strong impression that the program
is actually speaking about something. Further meaning
is the result of chance; on this basis "The Reaper" is
one of best (semantically, not poetically) of several
hundred poems produced by program.

BY JOE LEVINE
Does a man, in order to be a good
father, have to be an oppressive tyrant
'against whom his children can react and
rebel? Does a boy, in order to truly
become an independent man, have to
challenge and supplant his father?
The Great Santini, a film in which
Robert Duvall portrays a bullying marine
officer who treats his wife and children
like "the troops," sends its audiences
away asking these questions. Reactions
to the film tend to be very personal, and
therefore these arguments are usually the
sort that are hard to resolve: "What a
lousy S.O.B. of a father!" (this from thin
,or:- "Those
nervous types with glasses),'
kids may hate him now, but they're
gonna thank him some day! They'll grow
up with character because of him!"
(this from people with seventeen-inch
collars).
Regardless of whether one approves of Bull Meechum (the character
played by Duvall) as a father, The Great
Santini is likely to please as intelligent
and lively entertainment. The relationship between Bull and his sensitive,
gentle son Ben (Michael O'Keefe) rings
Even without Bull's external
true.

which have attempted to deal with the

Bull does to his wife and son prevents

most difficult.

The Veal" Woody Allen
BY STEPHEN H. BARR
Towards the middle of Stardust
Memories, Woody Allen's new film, a
struggling actor intercepts the worldfamous film director Sandy Bates(Woody
Allen) in a hotel lobby and says "I love
you. I mean, I love your work." This
slip is the essence of the film.
Throughout Woody Allen's career
as a comedian and a director, we have
assumed (as this actor does) that we can
understand Allen the man through his
work. In Allen's case, because he _stars in
' his own films, , he acknowledges the
autobiographical nature of his work, and
is often the butt of his funniest jokes, it is
particularly difficult to distinguish between the man and the work. Stardust
Memories is the ultimate autobiography,
in which Allen portrays a character we

immediately want to assume is himself - a
famous director of comedies.
This
character, Sandy Bates, proves to be the
most confusing and dislikable of Allen's
screen personas.
Bates is a director who makes
people laugh, but he is obsessed with
human suffering, which he considers
more important. His problem is not a
lack of inspiration, but of room to
create freely. At a weekend retrospective
of Bates' films, Allen surrounds Bates
with fawning fans who prey on his
privacy, his creativity, and his ability to
be Sandy Bates. Allen fills every corner
of his film with a supporting cast of sad
and grotesque creatures who become the
visual embodiment of what is stifling
Bates.

Nosey Kitty Kats

Chinatown: Film-Noir In Color
BY DAISY TAYLOR
Roman Polanski's Chinatown, starring Jack Nicholson, Faye Dunaway, and
John Huston, is film-noir in color. It is
hard-boiled cinema with an extra turn of
the screw. Polanski has protrayed a
thirsty Los Angeles summer in 1938 that
is seamier and more highly charged
with violence than it was in The Maltese
Falcon, The Big Sleep or Double Indemnity, but maintains the suspenseful, yet
brooding quality that those films had. He
lavishes the same attention onobjects and
details; we know what time it is, what
people drink and eat, their names, addresses and how they light their cigarettes. Polanski and his characters often
brilliantly mock the conventions of the
genre. But as a whole the film's message
is more shattering and its outlook more
bleak than its predecessors.
Jack Nicholson plays J.J. Giddes, a
small-time private eye, the smooth-talking
tough guy (especially likeable for being
something of a bumbler), whc, wants to
work outside the system and will spare
the little man if he can to get at the real
power figures behind him. Nicholson is
at his best in this role, bringing sensitivity
to a slick portrayal. Giddes is smart and
quick, but while working on a routine
adultery case, he stumbles into a complex

political moneymaking plot involving the
Los Angeles water supply (based on the
Otises and Chandlers scandal in 1905)
that is over his head. We move with
Giddes through LA's dried up river beds
and terra cotta court apartments under an
electric blue sky and a merciless sun. He
makes his way through a throng of
suspicious characters; twitching politicians, a hand-wringing rest home director, a
stone-faced Chinese butler, and a midget
mafioso with a stilletto. Everyone has
shifty eyes including Faye Dunaway, who
plays Mrs. Evelyn Molwray. Her husband
Hollis Molwray's role in the plot as
Commissioner of Water and Power for
Los Angeles puts her in the center of the
intrigue, making her a figure who seems
to attract violence from everyone including Giddes. Giddes is given a chance to
get out of it all, but true to the genre,
he falls in love with Mrs. Molwray, tries
to help her, and she, as we might expect,
never plays straight with him until it is
too late.
John Huston, as Dunaway's father,
the mysterious ranch magnate Noah
Cross, is also a party in the water plot.
Since John Huston also directed The
Maltese Falcon, one might suspect
that he worked in cahoots with Polanski
on this film. It seems appropriate that,
though they never appear together in the
film, they seem to play perverted versions
of the Falcon's sinister twosome, Sidney
Greenstreet and Peter Lorre. Huston is a
reptilian bulk wearing white, a characature of the slow moving villain who
knows how to live well.
However,
Cross is dangerous and unstoppable in a
way that Sidney Greenstreet never was.
Speaking in a coarse varody of Lorre's
seductive whine, Polanski plays the
rat-like midget who slits Nicholson's nose
with his stilletto. He is no pseudo-sophisticated dandy but coldly acts out his
playful threat as an enjoyable routine. As
he warns Nicholson,"Do you know what
happens to nosey kitty cats?", on the
screen he is directly facing the viewer.
Perhaps he is addressing his nosey audi-

ence too, warning us that we might
be in for a nasty surprise. We are shocked and disgusted by the violence of his
ensuing act. Through this self-reflexivity,
he is telling us that this is a more dangerous film than it's predecessor; anything
can happen. There's no pussy-footing
here.
Very little of the film's action takes
place
Chinatown.
in
Rather,
"Chinatown" functions as a loaded word
which evokes for Giddes memories of his
past that he would rather forget. He had
worked with the hard-nosed Escobar on
the police force in Chinatown years
before. Giddes runs into his old friend as
he is pursuing a lead in the case, and they
exchante a few cryptic words about their
shared experiences there. We see the
contrast between Escobar, who has just
made lieutenant by working his way up
through the system and Giddes, the
troublemaker, the one who gets emotionally involved in his work. From then on
Chinatown begins to creep into the film
more and more. Mrs. Molwray's Chinese
servants
Dunaway's
and
own
almond-eyed looks, accentuated in this
film, reinforce the motif until we see
Giddes physically and emotionally driven
back to Chinatown.

The most exciting works on

in 1980. All three are large-scale, rambl4,410# 4,4

‘,7
panels. Corinthian Covet, for example,
resembles a bizarre altar, with two
box-like extensions enclosing a collage
panel including lightbulbs and lifepreservers. On the walls of the extensions,
perpendicular to this surface, there are
mirrors that seem to expand the collage
into some undefinable space behind
everything. Despite corporate commissions and appearances in People magazine, Rauschenberg is still a creative
force of the highest order.
Sandy Bates (Allen) confronts the grotesque world of hi& sister and her husband

Rauschenberg Show
cont.from p. 13
The complete work is a field containing
many incidents. One's attention moves
from detail to detail - the painting must
be read, not perceived in a single glance.
Cloth has become the dominant iredium.
Rauschenberg used cloth in the early
50's, but not extensively. Now,he seems
to be reveling in the tremendous range
of patterns, colors, and textures available
to him. This switch from paint to fabric
is undoubtedly responsible for Rauschenberg's abandonment of silk-screened
images. Now he has returned. to a technique he developed in the 50's: solvent
transfer, a simple way of moving a
magazine photo from its paper substrate
directly onto cloth, with little change
in color or definition. In effect, the
image soaks right into the cloth, whereas
a silk-screened image is printed onto a
canvas with paint.
In every collage, cloth patches
recall curtains, clothing, tablecloths,
sheets, and upholstery: this sets up a
nostalgic or homey atmosphere, especially when the images cooperate (as they
often do). The direct presentation of the
photographic images is analogous to
homemade shrines (a wall in grandma's
house) or lockerroom pinups - the bulletin-board principle of tacking up transient
images.
Rauschenberg has gotten away
from highly urban, technological images,
again harking back to the 50's. Images of

Faye Dunaway as Mrs. Evelyn Molwray
The music, along with the camera
work, keeps up the suspense throughout.
Using camera techniques similar to those
employed in The Maltese Falcon,
Polanski often traps the character in a
tight frame. Cutting in very close to
Nicholson, he shows the viewer little of
the area surrounding him so that violence
always seems to tremble at the edge
of the screen.
In many ways Chinatown is more
than a suspense thriller. As Polanski
heightens the violence, Nicholson adds a
layer of sensitivity and vulnerability to
Giddes' character. With a tragic inevitability the two clash in a conclusion that
will probably leave you speechless no
matter how many times you've seen the
film before.

Clippers Open Oct. 25th

Charm City's Own Hockey Sensations Return
BY DAVE E1NOLF
During a press conference
held last week , the Baltimore
Clippers hockey team announced their 1980-81 season
schedule and ticket prices. The
Clippers als the signing of a
contract with WCBM radio, 680
AM, to broadcast the play-by-play for all 36 of the Clippers
regular season road games.
The Clippers will open their
home season Saturday, October
25th with an 8 o'clock contest
against the Richmond Rifles.
The Rifles, a farm team for the
New York Rangers, were one of
the Clippers' toughest opponents
in last year's maiden season.
Ticket for Clippers games are
$6.00 and $5.00, with special
$2.50 Upper Concourse seats
available immediately
at
all Hecht Co. Stores and the
Civic Center.
The Clippers schedule features 35 home games this season,
each as exciting as the opener
promises to be. Although the
Clippers have lost five of their
top players to the Minnesota
North Stars and their Oklahome
City farm team, skaters Barry
Alter, Gerry Ciarcia, Wes Coulson, Dave Herbst, Pierre Lagace,
Paul Pacific, and Tony Thomas
will al return when the Clippers
open their training camp at the
Civic Center October 14th. The
Clippers leading front line from
last season, that of Warren
Young, Ron Friest, and Henry
Taylor, has moved up, and Ron
Friest has been retained on the
North Stars roster even at this

late date. Goalie Jim Weaver,
who led the EHL in saves and
least goals scored, has hoped on
starting for _Oklahoma City this
season.
In addition to the seventeen
players on the roster announced
to date, the Clippers will be
holding a free agent trainin

camp 'this week, and will bring
around forty players to the Civic
Center in hopes of forming a
solid eighteen-man roster before
the start of the season.
Hockey fans should look for
intense competition among the
Clippers, the Richmond Rifles,
and Erie Blades. While these
three teams were all outstanding
in alst year's end-of-season
Mitchell Cup competition, fans
should by no means expect the

•

N-L
SPORTS

others to be lacking. The newly
formed Salem (Va.) Raiders and
the Syracuse Hornets, as well
as the returning Hampton (Va.)
Aces, should all add spice to the
season schedule. At the price
these tickets go for, the Clippers
cost less than a movie, and the
action is twice as intense. There
are no bad seats in the Civic
Center, because of the small
size of the arena. While seating
10,000 fans, the Civic Center

allows each of them an excellent
view. College students will be
wooed with various promotions
throughout the season, so watch
for them.
Finally, the front office is
conducting a talent search of
sorts, looking for performers to
fill in between periods and to
sing the Star-Spangled Banner.
All those interested should
phone Gary Thomas of the
Clippers at 727-0703.

Quiz Results
This week's quiz competition wasn't overwhelmingly heavy,
but we had our fair share of fine answers. Dorothy Pierson, David
Hollander and Eric Rocheteau all receive kudos for the most
correct answers. Although Pierson's and Rocheteau's subjective
answers were the best the quiz maestros still subjected it to the
luck of the draw. The winner was Eric Rocheteau of 4 E. 32nd
St.
The correct answers to this unbelievably tough quiz were:
I. Luis Aparicio; 2. Felix; 3. Allie Reynolds; 4. Jack Billingham:
5. Cesar Tovar; 6. Tim Foli; 7. Dave Leonhard; 8. Vida Blue; 9.
Johnny Oates; 10. Luis Tiant; 11. Tony . Chavez; 12. Alfred
Manuel Martin (from Number 1.); 13. Mike Cuellar; 14. Sam
McDowell; 15. Pat Kelly; 16. Clint Courtney; 17. Pat Dobson; 18.
36, Hal Brown; 19. Bob Feller pitched an Opening Day no-hitter.
Subjectively, the Mets have spawned more great players than
any other team in the last years. The whole idea, Dorothy, is that
they did trade them away, that's why the Mets are so much fun.
The Orioles, Dave, was not the right answer. As for broadcasters:
Howard Cosell was the right pick, but Tom Marr was almost as
good.
